title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0001
text: What is an interface in Java?

options.text: A blueprint of a class that contains abstract methods
A class with only static methods
A class that cannot be extended
A class with only final variables

explanation: An interface is a blueprint of a class that defines abstract methods to be implemented by classes.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0002
text: Which keyword is used to declare an interface in Java?
explanation: The 'interface' keyword is used to declare an interface in Java.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0003
text: Which of the following can an interface contain?
explanation: Interfaces can contain abstract, default, and static methods.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0004
text: Can an interface have instance variables?

options.text: No, only public static final variables are allowed
Yes, it can have instance variables

explanation: Interfaces can only have public static final variables, not instance variables.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0005
text: Can an interface have constructors?
explanation: Interfaces cannot have constructors because they cannot be instantiated.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0006
text: Which of the following is true about methods in interfaces before Java 8?

options.text: All methods are abstract and public

explanation: Before Java 8, all methods in interfaces were implicitly public and abstract.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0007
text: Which of the following is true about variables in interfaces?

options.text: They are public, static, and final by default

explanation: All variables in interfaces are implicitly public, static, and final.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0008
text: Can an interface extend another interface?

options.text: Yes, it can extend multiple interfaces
No, it cannot extend any interface

explanation: An interface can extend multiple interfaces, supporting multiple inheritance.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0009
text: Can a class implement multiple interfaces?

options.text: Yes, a class can implement multiple interfaces
No, a class can implement only one interface
Only if the interfaces have no methods
Only if the interfaces are abstract

explanation: A class can implement multiple interfaces, allowing multiple inheritance of type.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0010
text: Which of the following is true about default methods in interfaces?
explanation: Default methods in interfaces can have a body and provide default implementation.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0011
text: Which keyword is used by a class to inherit an interface?
explanation: A class uses the 'implements' keyword to inherit an interface.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0012
text: Can an interface extend a class?

options.text: No, interfaces can only extend other interfaces

explanation: Interfaces can only extend other interfaces, not classes.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0013
text: Can an interface have private methods?
explanation: Since Java 9, interfaces can have private methods to share code between default methods.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0014
text: Can an interface have static methods?
explanation: Since Java 8, interfaces can have static methods with implementations.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0015
text: Can an interface be declared final?

options.text: No, because it must be implemented
Only if it has no methods

explanation: An interface cannot be declared final because it must be implemented by other classes.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0016
text: Can an interface be instantiated directly?

options.text: Only if it has default methods
Only if it has static methods

explanation: Interfaces cannot be instantiated directly; they must be implemented by a class.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0017
text: Which of the following is true about multiple inheritance in interfaces?

options.text: Interfaces do not support multiple inheritance
Interfaces can extend only one interface

explanation: Interfaces support multiple inheritance by allowing one interface to extend multiple interfaces.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0018
text: Which of the following is true about implementing multiple interfaces with same method signature?

options.text: The class needs to implement the method only once
The class must implement the method multiple times
The class cannot implement both interfaces

explanation: If multiple interfaces have the same method signature, the implementing class needs to define it only once.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0019
text: Which of the following is true about interface inheritance?

options.text: An interface can extend multiple interfaces
An interface can extend only one interface
An interface cannot extend another interface

explanation: An interface can extend multiple interfaces, supporting multiple inheritance.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0020
text: Which of the following is true about interfaces and abstract classes?

options.text: Interfaces cannot have constructors, abstract classes can

explanation: Interfaces cannot have constructors, while abstract classes can.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0021
text: Which of the following is true about implementing an interface?

options.text: A class must implement all abstract methods of the interface
A class can skip implementing methods
A class can implement only one method

explanation: A class must implement all abstract methods of the interface unless it is declared abstract.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0022
text: Which of the following is true about interface variables?

options.text: They are implicitly public, static, and final

explanation: All variables in interfaces are implicitly public, static, and final.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0023
text: Which of the following is true about default methods in interfaces?
explanation: Default methods in interfaces can have a body and provide default implementation.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0024
text: Which of the following is true about static methods in interfaces?

options.text: They can be called using the interface name
They can be called using an object

explanation: Static methods in interfaces can be called using the interface name.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0025
text: Which of the following is true about private methods in interfaces?

options.text: They can be used to share code between default methods
They can be accessed by implementing classes

explanation: Private methods in interfaces can be used to share code between default methods.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0026
text: Which of the following is true about multiple inheritance in interfaces?

options.text: Interfaces do not support multiple inheritance
Interfaces can extend only one interface

explanation: Interfaces support multiple inheritance by allowing one interface to extend multiple interfaces.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0027
text: Which of the following is true about implementing multiple interfaces with same method signature?

options.text: The class needs to implement the method only once
The class must implement the method multiple times
The class cannot implement both interfaces

explanation: If multiple interfaces have the same method signature, the implementing class needs to define it only once.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0028
text: Which of the following is true about interface inheritance?

options.text: An interface can extend multiple interfaces
An interface can extend only one interface
An interface cannot extend another interface

explanation: An interface can extend multiple interfaces, supporting multiple inheritance.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0029
text: Which of the following is true about interfaces and abstract classes?

options.text: Interfaces cannot have constructors, abstract classes can

explanation: Interfaces cannot have constructors, while abstract classes can.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0030
text: Which of the following is true about interface methods?

options.text: They are public and abstract by default

explanation: All methods in interfaces are public and abstract by default unless declared otherwise.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0031
text: Which of the following is true about implementing interfaces?

options.text: A class can implement multiple interfaces
A class can implement only one interface
A class must implement all interfaces in the package

explanation: A class can implement multiple interfaces, allowing multiple inheritance of type.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0032
text: Which of the following is true about interface constants?

options.text: They are implicitly public, static, and final

explanation: All constants in interfaces are implicitly public, static, and final.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0033
text: Which of the following is true about interface inheritance and polymorphism?

options.text: Interfaces can only support compile-time polymorphism
Interfaces cannot be used in polymorphism

explanation: Interfaces support polymorphism by allowing objects of implementing classes to be referenced by interface type.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0034
text: Which of the following is true about interface references?

options.text: They can refer to objects of implementing classes
They cannot refer to any object
They can refer only to interface objects
They can refer only to abstract classes

explanation: Interface references can refer to objects of classes that implement the interface.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0035
text: Which of the following is true about interface default methods and multiple inheritance?

options.text: If two interfaces have the same default method, the implementing class must override it
The compiler automatically resolves the conflict
The class cannot implement both interfaces

explanation: If two interfaces have the same default method, the implementing class must override it to resolve ambiguity.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0036
text: Which of the following is true about interface inheritance and abstract classes?

options.text: An abstract class can implement an interface
An abstract class cannot implement an interface
An interface can extend an abstract class
An interface can implement an abstract class

explanation: An abstract class can implement an interface and may or may not provide implementations for its methods.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0037
text: Which of the following is true about interface methods and access modifiers?

options.text: All interface methods are public by default
All interface methods are private by default
All interface methods are protected by default
All interface methods are static by default

explanation: All interface methods are implicitly public by default.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0038
text: Which of the following is true about interface implementation and inheritance?

options.text: A class can extend another class and implement multiple interfaces
A class can extend multiple classes and implement one interface
A class can extend multiple classes
A class cannot implement interfaces if it extends a class

explanation: A class can extend one class and implement multiple interfaces in Java.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0039
text: Which of the following is true about interface constants?

options.text: They must be initialized at declaration
They can be initialized in constructors
They can be initialized in static blocks

explanation: Interface constants must be initialized at the time of declaration because they are final.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0040
text: Which of the following is true about interface and polymorphism?

options.text: Interfaces enable polymorphism by allowing multiple implementations
Interfaces cannot be used in polymorphism

explanation: Interfaces enable polymorphism by allowing multiple classes to implement the same interface differently.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0041
text: Which of the following is true about interface inheritance and method overriding?

options.text: Implementing classes must override all abstract methods
Implementing classes can skip overriding methods

explanation: Implementing classes must override all abstract methods of the interface.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0042
text: Which of the following is true about interface references and objects?

options.text: Interface references can refer to implementing class objects
Interface references cannot refer to any object
Interface references can refer only to abstract classes
Interface references can refer only to interfaces

explanation: Interface references can refer to objects of classes that implement the interface.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0043
text: Which of the following is true about interface and encapsulation?

options.text: Interfaces define behavior but not state
Interfaces define both behavior and state

explanation: Interfaces define behavior (methods) but not state (variables).

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0044
text: Which of the following is true about interface and abstraction?
explanation: Interfaces provide 100% abstraction as they define only method signatures and constants.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0045
text: Which of the following is true about interface and inheritance?

options.text: Interfaces can extend only one interface

explanation: Interfaces can extend multiple interfaces, supporting multiple inheritance.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0046
text: Which of the following is true about interface and implementation?

options.text: A class must implement all abstract methods of the interface
A class can skip implementing methods
A class can implement only one method

explanation: A class must implement all abstract methods of the interface unless it is declared abstract.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0047
text: Which of the following is true about interface and method visibility?

options.text: All interface methods are public by default
All interface methods are private by default
All interface methods are protected by default
All interface methods are static by default

explanation: All interface methods are implicitly public by default.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0048
text: Which of the following is true about interface and object creation?

options.text: Interfaces can be instantiated if they have default methods

explanation: Interfaces cannot be instantiated directly; they must be implemented by a class.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0049
text: Which of the following is true about interface and method overriding?

options.text: Implementing classes must override all abstract methods
Implementing classes can skip overriding methods

explanation: Implementing classes must override all abstract methods of the interface.

title: JavaOOPInterfaces - Q0050
text: Which of the following best describes an interface in OOP?

options.text: A contract that defines a set of methods to be implemented by classes
A class that cannot be extended
A class with only static methods
A class with only final variables

explanation: An interface defines a contract that specifies methods to be implemented by classes.
